value: aava_1.0_score
description

The AAVA 2.0 metadata represents a significant structural evolution from AAVA 1.0 while preserving core semantic meaning. Major architectural changes include nested object hierarchies and field renaming that may impact backward compatibility.
Core workflow concept preserved: both versions represent data integration workflows with technical specification agents. Business meaning remains consistent despite structural changes.
AAVA 2.0 introduces nested workFlowDetail object replacing flat workflowId/workflowName structure. This represents a 35-point structural deviation from the original flat schema.
workflowId field (1594) migrated to workFlowDetail.id (2147) with value change indicating different workflow instance.
workflowName renamed to workFlowDetail.name with formatting changes: 'DI_DataSpecs_Modelupdates_SN' to 'DI DataSpecs Modelupdates SN'.
Root-level nodes array replaced with workflowAgents array under new hierarchy. Array semantics preserved but location changed.
Agent agentName field renamed to name across all agent objects. Semantic meaning preserved.
New agentId field (3885, 3474, 3545) added in AAVA 2.0 providing unique agent identification not present in v1.
model field renamed to modelDeploymentName with version upgrade from 'gpt-4' to 'gpt-4.1' indicating model evolution.
tools array replaced with toolReferences array. AAVA 1.0 had populated tools, AAVA 2.0 shows empty toolReferences arrays.
task object structure flattened in AAVA 2.0. expectedOutput content moved to description field, task.description content preserved.
Tool references lost in migration: AAVA 1.0 had 'DI_Github_File_Writer_Z' tool, AAVA 2.0 shows empty toolReferences.
Task structure simplification may impact downstream systems expecting nested task.description and task.expectedOutput fields.
AAVA 1.0 JSON is syntactically valid with consistent internal structure and no broken references.
AAVA 2.0 JSON is syntactically valid with consistent internal structure and no broken references.
Field renaming without aliases may break existing integrations expecting original field names (workflowId, agentName, model, tools).
Workflow ID change from 1594 to 2147 suggests this represents a different workflow instance rather than pure schema evolution.
Model version upgrade from gpt-4 to gpt-4.1 indicates platform evolution with potential capability improvements.
AAVA 2.0 shows improved normalization with workFlowDetail object grouping related workflow metadata.
Addition of agentId provides better agent tracking and referential integrity in AAVA 2.0.
Both versions maintain consistent agent array structure with preserved agent descriptions and core functionality definitions.
Core business logic and agent capabilities remain functionally equivalent between versions despite structural changes.
Structural changes require mapping logic for field renames and hierarchy restructuring during version migration.
Loss of tool references in AAVA 2.0 may indicate incomplete migration or intentional architectural change requiring validation.
